headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: Warning to the World: Australia's Climate Disasters. Aired 8-9p ET

utterances.sentences: Madonna concert in Brazil last night. The queen of pop wrapping up her Celebration World Tour in Rio de Janeiro where fans waited for hours if not days to secure a good spot near Copa Cabana's beach. utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to THE WHOLE STORY. I'm Anderson Cooper.Australia's Great Barrier Reef is the world's largest marine habitat and one of the natural wonders the world. But it's now in its seventh mass bleaching events since 1998, which means the warming waters around Australia are killing the coral, turning this vibrant ecosystem into an underwater graveyard. This is just one of several climate crisis that's plagued Australia in recent years. There have been devastating wildfires and massive floods that are made parts of the country uninhabitable, and has decimated the population of native species like koalas. CNN's Ivan Watson has been reporting on the climate disaster in Australia for years, and he recently traveled back to see the evolving threats firsthand, and how people are both contributing to the crisis and trying to find ways to fix it. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE) IVAN WATSON, CNN SENIOR INTERNATIONAL CORRESPONDENT (voice-over): A once-in-a-lifetime experience. A chance to walk alone on a desert island in the middle of the Great Barrier Reef. All around me, turquoise blue water as far as the eye can see. I'm on the edge of one of the most beautiful marine habitats on the planet. A natural wonder of the world. An underwater jungle teeming with colors, movement, life. But on this journey off the coast of Australia, I learned about the death and destruction being caused by human activity, both on land and under the water. PROF. JODIE RUMMER, REEF SCIENTIST, JAMES COOK UNIVERSITY: The reef is not fine.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Unhealthy.

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: It's definitely feeling a lot of stress.WATSON (voice-over): The temperature of this water is rising. The result, coral is bleaching and dying.

utterances.speaker: KATE QUIGLEY, PRINCIPAL RESEARCH SCIENTIST, MINDEROO FOUNDATION
utterances.sentences: What is happening now in our oceans is like wildfires underwater. We're going to have so much warming that we're going to get to a tipping point and we won't be able to come back from that.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Growing up, I could never imagine one day visiting Australia. It was an exotic place on the other side of the planet. A land of koalas and kangaroos. Boasting natural treasures unlike any other place in the world. Decades later, I'm here enjoying this vibrant place. But also facing a frightening reality.

utterances.speaker: BARRY TRAILL, FIREFIGHTER AND CLIMATE CAMPAIGNER
utterances.sentences: It's ratcheting up and more and more people are being affected in their normal lives.

utterances.speaker: DAVID RITTER, CEO, GREENPEACE AUSTRALIA
utterances.sentences: Major destructive events. Fires, storms, floods. An unprecedented level. Unprecedented scale.PROF. OVE HOEGH-GULDBERG, CHIEF SCIENTIST, GREAT BARRIER REEF FOUNDATION: Humanity is being threatened at a rate which I'm not sure we really understand.

utterances.speaker: BILLY DUNLOP, KANGAROO ISLAND WILDLIFE CENTER
utterances.sentences: Coco's mom was hit and killed by a car. Yes.WATSON (voice-over): The small team at this wildlife center helps raise some of these orphaned animals by hand. Hi there. (Voice-over): Including Pearl, who seems pretty fond of humans. This is a little bit like holding a child, but pretty fuzzy. And the other part about this is the fur really is soft. (Voice-over): There are few things sweeter than cuddling a koala. My teammates couldn't wait for their turn. That's cute. (Voice-over): But then we learned the real reason Pearl is here.

utterances.speaker: DUNLOP
utterances.sentences: She had some burns through her ears and she still has lingering scar tissue there. We can't see obviously the parts of her hands and feet, but the leg was pretty badly burned on there as well.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Four years ago as a tiny joey Pearl survived apocalyptic forest fires, which raged across Australia. Australians now call it the Black Summer.

utterances.speaker: TRAILL
utterances.sentences: I cannot overstate the severity on the scale and intensity and the duration of the 2020 fires. There's nothing else like it in any recorded history in Australia.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Australia's extreme climate makes it more vulnerable to bushfires and floods, and climate change is exacerbating these natural disasters. Barry Traill, a volunteer firefighter and environmentalist, is seeing this firsthand.

utterances.speaker: TRAILL
utterances.sentences: It's going to get more often, more often. We're going to get more floods more often. If it's a wet year, it's going to flood more. If it's dry you're going to get hotter fires. That's just the physics of it.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: The fires destroyed thousands of homes and wiped out billions of animals.

utterances.speaker: DUNLOP
utterances.sentences: We had local people showing up here with 30, 40 animals in their car that they'd picked up on the way here or that they've, you know, gone back out to check their farm and had found, you know, a kangaroo with its legs, you know, melted off essentially.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Did you and your staff have to euthanize 300 koalas?

utterances.speaker: DUNLOP
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes. Yes, that was on us.Leaves a lasting scar, for sure. WATSON (voice-over): Those scars still raw for many survivors and for the families of the 33 people who died that summer. I'm Ivan. How are you doing? (Voice-over): Justin Lang meets me at the stretch of highway where the fire killed his father, Dick, and his brother Clayton. The fire caught them as they were driving home after helping protect a friend's farm from the blaze. This is glass from their vehicle, yes?

utterances.speaker: JUSTIN LANG, SON AND BROTHER OF FIRE VICTIMS
utterances.sentences: Yes. So that's the rear window.WATSON (voice-over): We find pieces of their truck still here four years later. Who thinks you could get burned to death driving on a road?

utterances.speaker: LANG
utterances.sentences: Yes. Exactly. They pulled off of the roads so they're out of the way but yes, the car combusted. The whole car was on fire.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: You mean the fire would have jumped from trees and the vegetation into the middle of a highway?

utterances.speaker: LANG
utterances.sentences: Yes. (INAUDIBLE).WATSON (voice-over): It's hard to imagine a bushfire engulfing a moving vehicle on a highway until you see footage like this.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We've got no choice. We got to get through this.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: The smoke so thick it turned day into night.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We are actually through the front, but we still got zero visibility.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: The fires even created their own weather system. Fired tornadoes ripping across open farmland. A frightening example of the sheer power of the blaze. For the island's small population, it meant all hands on deck.

utterances.speaker: DUNLOP
utterances.sentences: I was splitting my time between jumping on a truck and, you know, doing fire groundwork and, you know, being here and doing wildlife works. So days during that fire where there was nothing anyone could do. You know, the weather was too severe and the fire was too hot.This shows the area that was burned in 2019 and 2020. That fire burned 49 percent of the island's total land area.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: 49 percent, and Kangaroo Island is one of the biggest islands.

utterances.speaker: DUNLOP
utterances.sentences: It is third. Third largest island in Australia and --

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: And half of it burned.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: On Kangaroo Island.

utterances.speaker: DA SILVA
utterances.sentences: On Kangaroo Island.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Which has a population of about 5,000 people.

utterances.speaker: DA SILVA
utterances.sentences: That's right. So a lot more koalas than people. After the fires, it was probably more like 5,000 to 10,000. So it had a major impact on koalas.WATSON (voice-over): We head into the forest. These scientists are tracking what's left of the island's koala population. Using satellite radio collars to pinpoint their location.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: You see it?

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, there it is.(Voice-over): Our first discovery was unfortunately pretty bleak.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.sentences: But a few miles down the road, we have more luck.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.sentences: Huh.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Hi there.(voice-over): They weigh and check a female named Sunny before setting her free.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE

Take a look over here, part of the tree she's standing on still bears scorch marks from the previous fires here, which are believed to have killed off more than half of the population of the wild koalas on Kangaroo Island.This animal is a symbol of this country.

utterances.speaker: DA SILVA
utterances.sentences: It's an iconic species.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Is it in trouble?

utterances.speaker: DA SILVA
utterances.sentences: It's very much in trouble. Highly endangered. It may -- well, we're seeing it going locally extinct in different populations on the east coast.WATSON (voice-over): Populations decimated by disease and habitat loss from logging and wildfires that are ravaging Australia.

utterances.speaker: DA SILVA
utterances.sentences: All of those catastrophic climate change impacts are directly affecting koala populations in Australia.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Do you think this fire was a product of client climate change?

utterances.speaker: LANG
utterances.sentences: I think ultimately it was.WATSON (voice-over): An Australian government report concluded the same. Harder to measure the impact on people like Justin Lang, still mourning after the Black Summer Fires killed his father and brother.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: I'm standing on a tiny part of the Great Barrier Reef. It is the world's largest marine habitat. And to see its true beauty you have to go underneath the waves.(Voice-over): This isn't my first visit to the Great Barrier Reef. Six years ago, I came here to film a CNN report about this natural wonder of the world armed with only a mask and a snorkel. That was pretty spectacular. (Voice-over): This time, I'm scuba certified. My guide is Professor Jodie Rummer, a reef scientist at James Cook University. How many species did we see of marine life just now?

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm a fish person. There's over 1500 species of fish here on the Great Barrier Reef.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: How many do you think we saw?

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: You can see them all today, but 100 species?

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: A hundred?

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: Yes. It's an underwater rainforest. It's the most diverse (INAUDIBLE) on the planet. Above or underwater, I would argue. And it's been my inspiration for my entire career.WATSON (voice-over): We're diving in February, the peak of the Australian summer. This is like bathwater up here.

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: Right. Yes, we're in the sort of lowered mid-90 Fahrenheit.WATSON (voice-over): Jodie repeatedly shows me coral that's turned bone white.

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: The reef is not fine. A lot of corals were at various stages of bleaching. And some had already been overrun with algae.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Dead.

utterances.speaker: RUMMER
utterances.sentences: Dead. Yes, dead.WATSON (voice-over): Up close it's a pretty depressing sight. Coral basically being cooked and killed by unusually warm water. What we see beneath the surface confirmed several weeks later by the Australian government.

utterances.speaker: TANYA PLIBERSEK, AUSTRALIAN MINISTER OR ENVIRONMENT AND WATER
utterances.sentences: Our scientists have told us that we're facing a mass bleaching event. This is the seventh mass bleaching event since 1998.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Australia is experiencing a global record-breaking marine heatwave.

utterances.speaker: POPPY HARLOW, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: This extreme heat is causing what some scientists are calling the worst coral bleaching the state has ever seen.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We come here to determine how the coral reefs off the Florida Peninsula are coping with unprecedented ocean heat.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: In 2023, this weather pattern caused a massive die off of coral off the coast of Florida.HOEGH-GULDBERG: What happened in Florida or the Eastern Caribbean in the last couple of months was sort of shocking. And we're seeing similar thing happening at the moment on the Great Barrier Reef.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Ove Hoegh-Guldberg basically predicted this a quarter century ago. In this 1999 article, he wrote thermally triggered coral bleaching events will increase in frequency and severity in the next few decades. Corals are not keeping up with the rate of warming and they may be the single largest casualty of business as usual greenhouse policies. The article sparked a nasty backlash.Did you anticipate death threats in response to an academic research paper? HOEGH-GULDBERG: No, not at all. I also, you know, OK, what's going on here? You know, and you put it in front of you. How ridiculous?

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Have your predictions from 1999 followed that model?HOEGH-GULDBERG: We are pretty close to what we predicted would happen has happened. WATSON (voice-over): As carbon emissions drive climate change, the warming temperatures of the world's oceans keep breaking records. HOEGH-GULDBERG: Not more than about 5 percent to 10 percent.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: At this rate, Ove predicts only a fraction of the world's coral will still be alive 25 years from now.You're talking about a mass die off. HOEGH-GULDBERG: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Has this moved past coral reefs bleaching?HOEGH-GULDBERG: Yes. So this is what's fascinating and quite terrifying is that the number of disasters that are happening is increasing on a decade by decade space, be that a huge forest fires in many parts of the world or massive floods. WATSON (voice-over): Some of Australia's most recent floods, the port city of Cairns, a main gateway to the Great Barrier Reef. On December 18th, 2023, the worst rains in decades flood parts of the city.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The whole street was a river.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Including the home of Thomas Herridge and Trini Jacial Lillo.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Deep water.

utterances.speaker: TRINIDAD JACIAL LILLO, FLOOD VICTIM
utterances.sentences: The water were up to here when we left by.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Carrying the girls.

utterances.speaker: LILLO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The most expensive natural disaster in Australia's history.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: If we weren't looking at it with our own eyes it will be actually hard to even comprehend.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Power lines, that's how high the water is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: That's what we're dealing with, Larry and Carrie (PH), so excuse me if I keep watching my head. We're dodging out the powerlines.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Please do.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Just didn't see it possible that it was going to get to this stage.WATSON (voice-over): February 2022, Lismore. The worst flood in its history turns this small city into a lake. In a region already prone to flooding, the scale of this disaster catches authorities by surprise. At least four people died, thousands need to be rescued. Among them, Kate Stroud. This road, was this your escape route?

utterances.speaker: KATE STROUD, FLOOD VICTIM
utterances.sentences: Yes. So once we were rescued from our kitchen window by the gentleman on the jet ski, we were on top of the water, which we then had to duck beneath these power lines.

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: So that's the level that the flood came into this building in that flood.WATSON (voice-over): Kate is an artist and longtime resident of Lismore. This is your house?

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: Yes. It was my house.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Was your house.

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: I don't live here anymore.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Why don't you want to move back in?

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: Because you can't move back into a place where you know that that can happen again.WATSON (voice-over): In the early hours of February 28th, floodwaters fill their backyard.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Look at this.

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: This is the flood, getting into our house.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: The rain doesn't stop, the water just keeps coming. Kate takes shelter in the attic.

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: We'd saved everything we possibly could so there's no point in being in toxic water that was freezing cold and we hadn't slept for, you know, 24, 48 hours.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: A stranger on a passing jet ski rescues Kate.

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: Some other surreal things that made it really feel like it was out of this world was that there were cattle on the top of some of the shop tops.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: And the care on the roof.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: In the aftermath, a grueling cleanup. More than 70,000 tons of debris collected from the main shopping district alone.What was the state of your home when you saw it again?

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: Completely covered in a thick sludge of river mud and filth.WATSON (voice-over): The filth so bad returning residents don't know where to begin. Two years later, Lismore streets appeared tidy and clean but look closer, and you see homes and businesses boarded up, casualties of the flood. Steve Krieg had only been Lismore's mayor for a matter of weeks when the 2020 flood hit. It ruined his home and business. How is the community doing now two years on?

utterances.speaker: STEVE KRIEG, LISMORE MAYOR
utterances.sentences: You know, it's still very fresh in everyone's mind. It's fractured our community somewhat. A lot of our residents that live on the floodplain have moved due to necessity as far as finances or emotional impact.WATSON (voice-over): More than 1500 Lismore residents, many of whom could not afford insurance, still live in temporary government housing. Did you have to be rescued?

utterances.speaker: PETER ROYCE, FLOOD VICTIM
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did. I nearly drowned.WATSON (voice-over): 75-year-old Peter Royce spent hours trapped on the roof of his house. If it was fixed up, would you want to go back to it?

utterances.speaker: ROYCE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Why is that?

utterances.speaker: ROYCE
utterances.sentences: Oh, no. I wouldn't want to live in a flood zone ever again.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: It was that terrifying.

utterances.speaker: ROYCE
utterances.sentences: Yes, absolutely.WATSON (voice-over): Authorities failed to predict the severity of the February 2022 flood in Lismore.

utterances.speaker: ELIZABETH MOSSOP, URBAN PLANNER, LIVING LAB NORTHERN RIVERS
utterances.sentences: It's really about the climate becoming unstable.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Some urban planners want Australia to stop building on vulnerable flood plains.Do societies have to consider giving up on some locations?

utterances.speaker: MOSSOP
utterances.sentences: I do think that that is one of a range of things that has to be in in the toolbox.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Do you think a flood like this could happen again?

utterances.speaker: KRIEG
utterances.sentences: Yes. I'd be naive to say it'll never happen again.WATSON (voice-over): Despite the threat, the mayor of Lismore is doubling down. He opened a new business not far from the river.

utterances.speaker: KRIEG
utterances.sentences: This is my home. It's a place that I know and I love it. I don't want to leave anywhere else and if I'm not prepared to invest in the city, how can I ask anyone else to?

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: It will flood again. We just don't know when and we don't know how deep.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Kate isn't taking any chances. She's found a new home on higher ground outside of the city.

utterances.speaker: STROUD
utterances.sentences: There's a lot of people that are still really struggling even with the sound of rain.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: For the next phase of my journey, I'm headed back out to the Great Barrier Reef.

utterances.speaker: PETER GASH, LEASEHOLDER, LADY ELLIOTT ISLAND
utterances.sentences: OK. So we're going to put you up here, Ivan.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: We're looking at the beautiful Lady Elliot Island, the first island on the southern end of the Great Barrier Reef.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: This is literally the start of this massive marine habitat right here.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: The world's largest barrier reef starts right here.WATSON (voice-over): Landing here is tricky.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: We have to deal with the short runway with crosswinds and it's quite bumpy.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: The runway is only 650 meters long.Touchdown.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: You got it?

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Got it. Yes. Wow. GASH

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Thank you. That was incredible.(Voice-over): My pilot is Peter Gash. He's not just a pilot, he basically owns the island. Leasing it from the Australian government and running an eco-resort here with his family.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: We made it our life's worth. My wife and I married. I went and learned to fly airplanes so I could bring people here.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Peter wastes no time taking me out to see the island's underwater menagerie.You look as comfortable underwater as you are in the sky.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: Hey, Ivan, I came here 40 years ago, went underwater, and absolutely fell in love with the place. And how could you not? You've seen what it's like down there.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: I've never swam next to a sea turtle before. It's incredible. They just kind of glide along and they don't really seem to care that a human is kind of gasping and flipping around next to them.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: Because humans have not bothered the animals for a long time since it's been made a protected zone. Because humans don't interfere which is look but don't touch. we don't spear, we don't fish, the wildlife is completely comfortable with us.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: These waters regularly visited by manta rays, and a resident dolphin named Bubbles. Meanwhile, above the surface, the island teams with seabirds.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: At its peak, it's in excess of 200,000 birds.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: On this tiny island.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: In this tiny little island. It's crazy to think that.WATSON (voice-over): Peter gives me a tour. What are these tags, for example?

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: That's our water storage.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: Like I said we do salinize the water when we store, then we keep about 10 and 12 days of water.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: How much of the energy being used by the resort comes from solar power?

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: Hundred percent of it.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Hundred percent. GASHWATSON (voice-over): Lady Elliott Island didn't always look like this. In the 19th Century, settlers mined the island for bird guano, leaving the place mostly barren hard coral. You can almost count the trees that were here in 19th Century.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. There was almost nothing. This is a manmade forest. Everything you see here, we planted. I couldn't walk here 15 or 20 years ago because it was so rough. Here now, we've got natural soil. Magnificent.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Is this from your compost?

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: No, it's from the trees. And the bird, that's bird poop, dead birds and trees and mulch. This is naturally forming. This is the island regrowing again. The island grows about three millimeters a year.WATSON (voice-over): Peter is trying to run a profitable tourist resort and sustain this remarkable little island.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: Peter's message of hope is inspiring, but it's tempered by something we see underwater. Amid the reef sharks and sea turtles, there's coral bleached white. Enough to worry this island's greatest enthusiast.

utterances.speaker: GASH
utterances.sentences: What we do see is more and more bleaching, more and more stress on the corals. Hot water, the water warming, the environment changing and bringing up the water. To me that's a big risk.

utterances.speaker: WATSON
utterances.sentences: The damaged coral here part of the mass bleaching event caused by the marine heatwave along the Great Barrier Reef. A phenomenon that could threaten the entire ecosystem.On this journey, I've seen how nature can rebound. This island is an example of a place that was a barren rock 30, 40 years ago, has regrown a forest, but there's another reality that's been hammered home. So even the success story here on this tiny island is vulnerable to the much larger pattern of climate change that we're seeing around the globe. (COMMERCIAL BREAK) [20:51:10] WATSON: Every day trains rumble past, carrying coal to Newcastle. This is the last stop on my journey across Australia. An industrial city with a very busy port.
